A300: Winglet design (A300 typically lacks winglets or has smaller winglets compared to A340)
Absence of a characteristic "S-duct" engine intake on the tail
Lack of wingtip fences or sharklets (classic A300s)
Lacks the distinctive "hump" of the A380's upper deck
Tailcone design: The tailcone of the A310 is more tapered compared to the more rounded design of the A300.
Cockpit windows with a more angular design
A310: Only two engines, one under each wing
Cockpit windows: The A310 has a distinct shape for its cockpit windows compared to the Boeing 767.
Broader, taller vertical stabilizer (tail fin) on the A310
Absence of the distinctive tail engine found on the DC-10
Distinctive tailcone shape (more pointed on A310)
Different engine placement and size (depending on the variant)
Single full passenger deck (no partial upper deck as in some larger aircraft)
More modern fuselage design with fewer windows
Fuselage shape: The A310 typically has a shorter, more compact fuselage than the longer fuselage of the Boeing 767.
A320: Two Overwing emergency exits on each side
Winglets with a vertical upturn instead of raked wingtips
Shorter fuselage compared to A330 or A380
Cockpit windows with a more squared shape
Wing mounted engines that appear slightly lower
Two main landing gear wheels on each side
Typical Airbus nose shape (rounded compared to pointed of some Boeings)
A330: Nose Shape: The A330 has a more rounded nose
Two engines (The A330 has two engines, while the DC-8 typically has four)
Winglets: A330 typically has wingtip devices known as winglets or sharklets
Absence of a pronounced "hump" at the rear of the fuselage
Cockpit Windows: The A330 has a more curved and downward-sloping cockpit window line
Absence of a second set of landing gears in the center of the fuselage
A340: Absence of a hump on the upper deck
Longer fuselage relative to wing size
A380: Double-deck design with upper and lower passenger cabins
Distinctive hump running the entire length of the fuselage
Four jet engines (two on each wing)
Double-deck fuselage (spanning the entire length of the aircraft)
ATR-72: Twin turboprop engines mounted on the wings
Two turboprop engines with six-blade propellers
Larger, more prominent landing gear located on the wings
Absence of jet engines mounted at the rear of the fuselage
An-12: Distinctive nose shape (often with a glazed nose compartment)
Military markings or stenciling if used by armed forces
BAE 146: Four engines mounted under the wings
Landing gear configuration (retracts into fairings on the wings)
BAE-125: Rear-mounted twin engines located on either side of the fuselage
T-tail configuration with horizontal stabilizers mounted on top of the vertical stabilizer
Two engines mounted at the rear of the fuselage
Compact fuselage with a sleeker design
Beechcraft 1900: Twin turboprop engines mounted on the wings
Boeing 707: Four engines mounted under the wings
Distinctive "eyebrow" cockpit windows above the main front windows
Wing design with a kinked trailing edge
Conventional tailplane design (versus T-tail in some others)
More rounded and shorter fuselage shape
Boeing 727: Three engines (two mounted on the rear fuselage and one in the tail through an S-duct)
Distinctive S-shaped intake under the tail for the center engine
T-tail design (horizontal stabilizers mounted on top of the vertical stabilizer)
Rear stairway (built-in airstairs that can be lowered from the rear fuselage)
Distinctive small dorsal fin on top of the rear fuselage
Boeing 737: Winglets at the wingtips (depending on the model and generation)
Twin engines mounted beneath the wings
Number of main landing gear wheels: typically four wheels in the main gears on each side
Number of doors: fewer doors along the side of the fuselage compared to larger aircraft
Absence of a hump on the upper deck
Boeing 747: Double-deck configuration with additional windows on the upper deck
Distinct hump on the upper deck near the front
Distinctive hump on the upper deck
Hump on the upper deck, extending from the front of the plane to about one-third to halfway back
Larger overall size and wider wingspan
Four engines mounted under the wings
More prominent and taller vertical stabilizer
Boeing 757: Two large turbofan engines mounted under the wings
Distinctive cockpit windshield shape, with more pronounced angles
Four-wheeled main landing gear (tandem bogie arrangement)
More pointed and thinner vertical stabilizer (tail fin)
No hump on the upper deck area
Boeing 767: Two engines mounted under the wings
Lack of a noticeable hump on the upper fuselage
Larger, slightly taller vertical stabilizer (tail fin)
Boeing 777: Larger overall length and fuselage size
Two engines (versus four engines in some similar classes)
C-130: Cargo door on the side of the fuselage toward the rear
Wider and more robust landing gear
Distinctive tail shape with a T-tail configuration
Distinctive square-shaped cargo ramp and door at the rear
Bulky and rugged appearance for tactical airlift operations
Shorter, stockier landing gear suited for rough airstrips
Squared-off fuselage rear for loading and unloading cargo
C-47: Cargo doors and paratroop jump doors
CRJ-200: Engines mounted closer to the fuselage
T-tail configuration with smaller horizontal stabilizers

CRJ-700: Engines mounted on the rear fuselage at wing-level

Regional jet design with a lower height profile
Cessna 172: Conventional tail with a single vertical stabilizer
Single-engine with a propeller at the nose

Cessna Citation: Tricycle landing gear with main gear retracting into wings or fuselage

Wing-mounted engines (two under the wings, one on the tail)
Tail engine intake: The DC-10's tail-mounted engine has a prominent S-duct intake design
Lack of winglets on the wingtips
DC-6: Conventional tail structure without a T-tail

Window arrangement: Longer row of passenger windows along the fuselage
DC-8: Number of engines: Four engines mounted under the wings
Tail design: Conventional empennage without a T-tail
DC-9: Absence of an engine on the vertical stabilizer (tail)

Biplane configuration (two wings stacked one above the other)
Simple, rounded fuselage design typical of early 20th-century light aircraft

Dash 8: Engine nacelles close to the aircraft body

cabin windows evenly spaced and flush

T-tail: The Falcon 900 features a T-tail configuration
